DOC.HEAD: Selections From Beckett's Works
With PM-Obit-Beckett, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a selection of quotations from the writings of Samuel Beckett, the playwright who died Friday:

From ``Waiting for Godot'': We are all born mad. Some remain so.
Estragon: Let's go. Vladimir: We can't. Estragon: Why not? Vladimir: We're waiting for Godot.
Nothing happens, nobody comes, nobody goes, it's awful!

From ``Malone Dies'': Death must take me for someone else.
To be buried in lava and not turn a hair, it is then a man shows what stuff he is made of. To know he can do better next time, unrecognizably better, and that there is no next time, and that it is a blessing there is not, there is a thought to be going on with.
From ``All that Fall'': This dust will not settle in our time. And when it does some great roaring machine will come and whirl it all sky-high again.
From ``Endgame'': Clov: Do you believe in the life to come? Hamm: Mine was always that.
From ``Murphy'': There is no return game between a man and his stars.

From ``Stirrings Still,'' Beckett's last published work: A clock afar struck the hours and half-hours. The same as when among others Darly once died and left him. Strokes now clear as if carried by a wind now faint on the still air. Cries afar now faint now clear. Head on hands half hoping when the hour struck that the half-hour would not and half fearing that it would not. Similarly when the half-hour struck. Similarly when the cries a moment ceased. Or merely wondering. Or merely waiting. Waiting to hear.
